Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A doctor diagnoses that a sick man has eaten too much chicken (fruit). The doctor’s son asks how he knew this. The doctor answers that he looked through the man’s garbage & noticed the bones (peels). The son is called to a different sickbed. He notices a donkey sad-dle under the bed (by the door) & diagnoses that the sick man has eaten too much donkey meat (horse & wagon, a pillow). The doctor’s son is ridiculed. Or, he diagnoses that a sick woman has overexerted herself in church work (politics), because he finds a clergyman (politician) under her bed.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A veterinarian (charlatan) is called to treat a sick cow. He tells the farmer (farmhand) to hold the animal’s mouth open & look in. The veterinarian holds up the cow’s tail & holds a lantern under it. The farmer looking into the mouth cannot see the light, so the veterinarian says the cow suffers from constipation.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A court jester wants to show the king that the most common profession in the kingdom is that of doctoring. He ties a cloth around his head & pretends that he has a toothache. Everyone who comes by offers advice about treatments for toothache, & thus the king can see how many doctors there are.

Classifications: What is Good for One is Not Good for All
Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A sick smith comes to a quack doctor who prescribes that he should eat bacon pancakes (cauliflower with bacon) three times a day. Three days later the doctor sees the smith working hard & thinks that his prescription cured him. Later, a sick tailor comes to the same doctor & the doctor gives him the same prescription. When the tailor dies, the doctor decides that his prescription was good for smiths but not for tailors.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about people who are insane.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about foreigners (people from a neighboring country or town). Often the people are stereotyped, e.g. as thieves, as lazy, or as malicious. Some of the anecdotes refer to their ancestors: they are said to descend from some kind of animal.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about noblemen.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes consisting of humorous dialogs between a criminal & the hangman, or in which the hanging can not take place because the gallows falls apart.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about people of a particular religion.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: Anecdotes & Philosophers

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A philosopher (Thales) always looks up in order to observe the stars. He falls into a well. An old woman asks him why he wants to learn about the stars, when he cannot even walk on earth without stumbling.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A king wants to destroy a city. A phil-osopher from the city comes & asks for mercy. The king says that he always does the opposite of what people ask him to do. The philosopher asks him to destroy the city & thus saves it.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: The king asks the cynic (Diogenes) what he can do for him. The philosopher asks him to move his shadow & get out of his light. He says, “Don’t take away from me what you can’t give me”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: A bald man insults a philosopher. The philosopher replies, “I envy (praise) your hair. It left you a long time ago”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: An illegitimate boy who throws stones is warned by a cynic, “Watch out, you might hit your father”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: Diogenes carries a lantern through the marketplace in broad daylight. When he is asked what he is doing, he replies, “Looking for an honest man”.

Subcategory: 1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of People
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various anecdotes about the philosopher Diogenes. Examples: (1) When Diogenes sees children drinking from their cupped hands, he gives up his own drinking cup. (2) A servant of the king sees Diogenes eating cabbage (washing lettuce) & says, “If you worked for my master, you would have better things to eat”. Diogenes answers, “If you would eat cabbage, you would not have to flatter your master”.

Classifications: The Boy on the Bear's (Wolf's) Tail
Variation Example: A boy (man, girl, woman) becomes lost (has run away from home or from his master, etc.). (In the forest,) he meets robbers (thieves, Gypsies, Indians) who put him into a cask. A wolf (fox, dog, bear) comes to eat the robbers’ leftovers (sniffs at the cask). The boy reaches out through a hole & seizes the animal by its tail (so that it cries out). It runs away dragging the cask behind it until the cask breaks. Often the boy discovers that he has been taken back home. (The animal loses its tail or is killed.) There is a northern group of variants in which a cabin boy an-noys the crew with his pranks (bad work, stupid conversation) or is blamed for a dangerous storm. The sailors throw him into the water in a cask along with some provisions (including honey) & tools. When he comes to a shore, he bores a hole & smears it with honey. Thus he lures a bear (fox, cow) & seizes its tail.
A hunter shoots a captured rabbit tied to a pole. He hits the string & breaks it. The rabbit escapes.

Classifications: The Boy in the Hallowed Tree
Variation Example: A young man plunges into (hides in) a hole in a tree. Woodcutters come to take the tree down. The young man speaks from inside the tree. This frightens them so that they run away, leaving their equipment (bread, horse) behind.

A man (soldier) who wants to enter a fortress jumps onto a cannon-ball that has been shot from a cannon. Half way there, he reconsiders his plan & decides not to go after all. He jumps onto another can-nonball that has been shot in the other direction & rides it back home.

Classifications: Man Carried Through the Air by Geese
Variation Example: A man (farmer, hunter) catches geese (ducks, cranes) by tying bread (bacon, worms) to a string. The geese come, eat the bread, & become tied one after another to the string. (A man catches geese by giving them liquor to drink & then ties them all to a string.) The hunter tries to take them home, but on the way they sud-denly all fly up at once & lift him up in the air. They take him to his house & set him down. He climbs home down through the chimney.

Classifications: Parrots Fly Away with a Tree
Variation Example: A man is annoyed by loud birds (parrots, crows) sitting in a tree. He climbs the tree & smears syrup on the branches. When the birds alight there again, he frightens them (with fireworks). The birds fly up carrying the tree with the man still in it along with them (to a city).

Classifications: The Man who Fell out of a Balloon
Variation Example: A man is carried to heaven in a balloon (by a bird), in an airplane). He tries to climb back down to earth on a rope (of sand, flax, chaff, but the rope is too short (breaks). The man falls & becomes stuck in the ground up to his neck. He runs home to get an axe (spade) to dig himself out.

Classifications: Man Caught in Log (Cleft Tree) Goes Home to Get Axe
Variation Example: A man is caught in a tree trunk (hole in a tree). He goes home & gets an axe to cut himself free.

Classifications: A Man Drinks from his Own Skull
Variation Example: A man takes his skull off & drinks from it (carries water in it, uses it to break ice). The skull falls into the water & a duck builds her nest inside it.

Classifications: Cattle Merchant's Voyage Across the Sea
Variation Example: A man floats across the sea on a raft. One after another, he brings a herd of cattle across to the op posite shore. He himself rides along with the last animal, holding on to its tail.
This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with exaggerations & lies.

A blind bear (wild sow) follows after a young bear (young boar) by holding its tail in his mouth. A hunter separates them by shooting a bullet through the young bear’s tail. He leads the blind bear home by holding on to the amputated tail of the young bear.
A hunter thrusts his fist into the mouth of an animal (wolf, bear) & reaches his arm in up to his shoulder. He seizes the animal’s tail (intestines) & turns it insideout.

Classifications: Fruit Tree Grows from Head of a Deer
Variation Example: A hunter uses a cherry pit to shoot a deer. A year or two later he recognizes the animal by the cherry tree that has grown between its antlers. This time he kills it.

Classifications: Tree Grows Out of a Horse & Gives Rider Shade
Variation Example: The broken backbone of a horse is repaired by a smith who pieces it together with a laurel sapling. The sapling grows into a tree which provides shade for the rider.

Classifications: Descent From the Sky on Rope of Sand (Chaff)
Variation Example: A man who is in the sky (on the moon, in another high place) wants to return to the earth. He makes a rope out of flax (leather, sand, chaff, dough, soap, intestines), but this is too short. He cuts a piece off the top & ties it to the bottom. The rope breaks & the man falls down to earth.
A man tells (in jest) about a place (town) where it was so cold that all the words (songs) froze in extreme cold as soon as they were spoken. When spring came the words thawed & could be heard again.
A huge fish (whale, several fishes) over-turns a ship & swallows the crew (a sailor). When later the fish is caught & its stomach is opened, all the men are still sitting inside & can be rescued.
A sailor goes across the ocean to see where it ends, where the tide comes from, & where the tide goes when it is out. On his journey he experiences various adventures (under water).

Classifications: Jumping Back to the Starting Place
Variation Example: A man tries to leap over water. Halfway across, he changes his mind, & returns to his starting place.

While chasing a hare, a hunting dog runs through a fence & splits himself into two parts. The hunter puts him back together, but with one pair of legs pointing upward. The dog recovers & learns to run on two legs. When he gets tired, he flips over & runs on the other two legs.

A hunter’s best dog dies. He has its skin made into a pair of mittens (piece of clothing, flask for drink) which he wears while hunting. Seeing some game (hare), he exclaims, “I wish I had my dog!” The gloves come off & chase the game.

Classifications: Snakebite Causes an Object to Swell
Variation Example: A snake (bee, hornet, dog) bites (stings) an object (tree, yoke, walking stick, axle of a wagon, stirrup) which swells to a monstrous size.
